messages.content: Identify the tickets in the database that have exceeded the initial response time according to the relevant documentation, and send reminder emails—based on the templates mentioned in the manual—to the respective responsible managers, as well as apology emails to all involved users.

messages.content:
{"type":"text","text":"PDF total pages: 5
Extracted page range: 1-5

=== Page 1 ===
Page 1 of 5MCP Inc. Service Standards & Operations
Handbook
Last Updated: June 2024
1. Purpose and Scope
This handbook outlines MCP Inc.’s operational standards, monitoring practices, and customer
interaction principles.
 It de�nes both customer-facing SLAs and internal operational reference guidelines.
 Sections marked as “Internal Policy” are not part of the externally-committed SLA and are included for
operational completeness only.
2. Internal System Availability Policy (Internal Use Only)
MCP maintains several internal benchmarks for monitoring service uptime across APIs, admin consoles,
and core infrastructure.
2.1 Console and API Availability
Automated health checks run every �ve minutes for API endpoints and management consoles.
Availability is calculated on a monthly rolling average excluding approved maintenance windows.
Any HTTP 5xx response or abnormal payload is logged as a service disruption in internal systems
(not public SLA).
2.2 Maintenance Window
A recurring Maintenance Window is scheduled on the second Thursday of each month from 3:00
PM–4:00 PM (PT).
During this period, some dashboards or administrative functions may be temporarily unavailable.
Any downtime in this window is excluded from end ‑ user SLA metrics.
3. Incident Priority De�nitions (Internal Classi�cation)

=== Page 2 ===
Page 2 of 5Although distinct from customer SLA response levels, MCP internally categorizes incidents to support
triage:
Priority Description Example
P1Major service outage or resource unavailability that halts
mission-critical functions.API gateway o�ine
P2 Service available but degraded or failing key functions.Search returning
incomplete results
P3 Minor issues with negligible customer impact. Cosmetic UI defect
Note: These internal priority levels are for technical operations and do not override customer
response time commitments.
4. Environment Recovery Guidelines (Internal
Operations)
In the event of Availability Zone (AZ) unavailability affecting internal test or pre-production
environments, MCP will initiate recovery within 12 hours of detection or authorization.
Recovery involves:
Redeploying stacks from baseline templates
Restoring data from the last approved restore point
This is a best-effort objective and independent of customer ticket processing.
5. Patch Management Policy (Internal Reference)
Critical security updates are applied to internal assets within 10 business days of vendor release.
Important updates are applied within two months of vendor release.
Applies to:
Supported operating systems
Pre-installed core application software
This policy is unrelated to customer-facing ticket turnarounds.
6. Core Service Level Agreement — Customer-Facing
Commitment
This section contains the agreed standards for customer communication and ticket handling.

=== Page 3 ===
Page 3 of 56.1 User Levels and Response Times
User Level First Reply Time Second Reply Time (if �rst reply is overdue)
Basic 72 hours 72 hours
Pro 36 hours 36 hours
Max 24 hours 18 hours
Notes:
First Reply Time: Maximum time from ticket creation to the �rst customer contact.
Second Reply Time: If the �rst reply exceeds the deadline, you must send an apology email
stating that the next reply will be sent within this time frame.
6.2 Templates
Note: The Placeholder in this section should be replaced to real values.
6.2.1 Customer Apology Email Template
Subject: Update on Your Service Request {TICKET_NUMBER}
Dear Customer,
We sincerely apologize for not responding to your service request {TICKET_NUMBER} within the
promised timeframe.
We commit to providing an initial solution or the latest status update within {SECOND_REPLY_TIME}
hours, and will continue following up until the issue is fully resolved.
For urgent matters, please contact us directly:
 Phone: 400-772-1234
We apologize again for any inconvenience this may have caused.
Best,
 MCP Inc., Customer Support Team
6.2.2 Manager Reminder Template
Note: Please list tickets in max →  pro →  basic order.
Subject: [Overdue Alert] Tickets Exceeding First Reply SLA
Dear Manager,

=== Page 4 ===
Page 4 of 5The following tickets have exceeded the SLA �rst reply time. Please prioritize and coordinate
processing:
{TICKET_NUMBER}: {Level}
 {TICKET_NUMBER}: {Level}
 {TICKET_NUMBER}: {Level}
Best,
 MCP Inc., Customer Support Team
7. Additional Operational Metrics (Non-SLA)
These performance metrics are tracked for internal monitoring purposes only and have no bearing on
customer SLAs.
7.1 Conformance Rate
Calculated monthly as the percentage of internal performance targets achieved.
Segmented by:
Infrastructure uptime
Average incident resolution by internal priority
Patch cycle completion rate
7.2 Service Credit Eligibility (Internal Reference to AWS Model)
Service Credits (if issued) are applied as a percentage discount on future internal cross-
department billing.
Maximum internal service credit per month: 30% of the allocated operational budget for the
affected service.
Credits are not transferable outside the organization.
8. Internal Reporting Work�ow
�. Detection: Automated systems log uptime and incident metrics every �ve minutes.
�. Classi�cation: Technical operations team assigns internal priority levels (P1, P2, P3).
�. Action: Appropriate recovery, patching, or monitoring adjustments.
�. Documentation: Metrics stored for quarterly performance review.
9. SLA Exclusions

=== Page 5 ===
Page 5 of 5The following do not count towards SLA performance metrics:
Authorized maintenance during the scheduled monthly window.
Downtime due to third-party upstream providers beyond MCP’s control.
Customer-requested delays or refusal of recommended action.
Failures in unsupported third-party software.
10. Glossary
First Reply Time: Interval between ticket creation and �rst customer contact.
Second Reply Time: Interval to follow-up after overdue �rst reply.
Maintenance Window: Designated time for pre-scheduled service work.
Incident Recovery: Process to restore unavailable systems or services.
Conformance Rate: Measure of how often internal targets are met.
11. Revision History
Version Date Changes Author
1.0 Jun 2024 Initial release Ops Team
1.1 Jun 2024 Added internal operational sections & glossary Ops Team","annotations":null}

function.name: snowflake-read_query
function.arguments:
{"query":"WITH slas AS (
  SELECT 'Basic' AS level, 72 AS first_hours, 72 AS second_hours
  UNION ALL SELECT 'Pro', 36, 36
  UNION ALL SELECT 'Max', 24, 18
),
joined AS (
  SELECT 
    t.ID AS ticket_id,
    t.TICKET_NUMBER,
    t.CREATED_AT,
    t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT,
    u.ID AS user_id,
    u.NAME AS user_name,
    u.EMAIL AS user_email,
    u.SERVICE_LEVEL,
    u.CUSTOMER_MANAGER AS manager_email,
    s.first_hours,
    s.second_hours,
    IFF(t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT IS NULL, DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP()), DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT)) AS hours_to_first_response
  FROM SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.SUPPORT_TICKETS t
  JOIN SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.USERS u ON u.ID = t.USER_ID
  JOIN slas s ON s.level = u.SERVICE_LEVEL
)
SELECT 
  ticket_id,
  TICKET_NUMBER,
  SERVICE_LEVEL,
  user_id,
  user_name,
  user_email,
  manager_email,
  first_hours,
  second_hours,
  hours_to_first_response,
  CASE WHEN hours_to_first_response > first_hours THEN TRUE ELSE FALSE END AS exceeded
FROM joined
WHERE hours_to_first_response > first_hours
ORDER BY 
  CASE SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Max' THEN 1 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 2 WHEN 'Basic' THEN 3 ELSE 4 END,
  CREATED_AT;"}

messages.content: {"type":"text","text":"Error: Calls to read_query should not contain write operations","annotations":null}

function.name: snowflake-read_query
function.arguments:
{"query":"SELECT 
  t.ID AS ticket_id,
  t.TICKET_NUMBER,
  t.CREATED_AT,
  t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT,
  u.ID AS user_id,
  u.NAME AS user_name,
  u.EMAIL AS user_email,
  u.SERVICE_LEVEL,
  u.CUSTOMER_MANAGER AS manager_email,
  CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Basic' THEN 72 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 36 WHEN 'Max' THEN 24 END AS first_hours,
  CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Basic' THEN 72 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 36 WHEN 'Max' THEN 18 END AS second_hours,
  CASE WHEN t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT IS NULL THEN DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP()) ELSE DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT) END AS hours_to_first_response
FROM SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.SUPPORT_TICKETS t
JOIN SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.USERS u ON u.ID = t.USER_ID
QUALIFY hours_to_first_response > first_hours
ORDER BY 
  CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Max' THEN 1 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 2 WHEN 'Basic' THEN 3 ELSE 4 END,
  t.CREATED_AT"}

function.name: snowflake-read_query
function.arguments:
{"query":"WITH joined AS (
  SELECT 
    t.ID AS ticket_id,
    t.TICKET_NUMBER,
    t.CREATED_AT,
    t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT,
    u.ID AS user_id,
    u.NAME AS user_name,
    u.EMAIL AS user_email,
    u.SERVICE_LEVEL,
    u.CUSTOMER_MANAGER AS manager_email,
    CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Basic' THEN 72 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 36 WHEN 'Max' THEN 24 END AS first_hours,
    CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Basic' THEN 72 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 36 WHEN 'Max' THEN 18 END AS second_hours,
    CASE WHEN t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT IS NULL THEN DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP()) ELSE DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT) END AS hours_to_first_response
  FROM SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.SUPPORT_TICKETS t
  JOIN SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.USERS u ON u.ID = t.USER_ID
)
SELECT *
FROM joined
WHERE hours_to_first_response > first_hours
ORDER BY 
  CASE SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Max' THEN 1 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 2 WHEN 'Basic' THEN 3 ELSE 4 END,
  CREATED_AT;"}

function.name: snowflake-read_query
function.arguments:
{"query":"SELECT * FROM (
  SELECT 
    t.ID AS ticket_id,
    t.TICKET_NUMBER,
    t.CREATED_AT,
    t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT,
    u.ID AS user_id,
    u.NAME AS user_name,
    u.EMAIL AS user_email,
    u.SERVICE_LEVEL,
    u.CUSTOMER_MANAGER AS manager_email,
    CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Basic' THEN 72 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 36 WHEN 'Max' THEN 24 END AS first_hours,
    CASE u.SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Basic' THEN 72 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 36 WHEN 'Max' THEN 18 END AS second_hours,
    CASE WHEN t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT IS NULL THEN DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP()) ELSE DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT) END AS hours_to_first_response
  FROM SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.SUPPORT_TICKETS t
  JOIN SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.USERS u ON u.ID = t.USER_ID
) AS joined
WHERE hours_to_first_response > first_hours
ORDER BY 
  CASE SERVICE_LEVEL WHEN 'Max' THEN 1 WHEN 'Pro' THEN 2 WHEN 'Basic' THEN 3 ELSE 4 END,
  CREATED_AT"}

function.name: snowflake-read_query
function.arguments:
{"query":"SELECT 
  t.ID AS ticket_id,
  t.TICKET_NUMBER,
  t.CREATED_AT,
  t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT,
  u.ID AS user_id,
  u.NAME AS user_name,
  u.EMAIL AS user_email,
  u.SERVICE_LEVEL,
  u.CUSTOMER_MANAGER AS manager_email,
  CASE UPPER(u.SERVICE_LEVEL) WHEN 'BASIC' THEN 72 WHEN 'PRO' THEN 36 WHEN 'MAX' THEN 24 END AS first_hours,
  CASE UPPER(u.SERVICE_LEVEL) WHEN 'BASIC' THEN 72 WHEN 'PRO' THEN 36 WHEN 'MAX' THEN 18 END AS second_hours,
  CASE WHEN t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT IS NULL THEN DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP()) ELSE DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT) END AS hours_to_first_response
FROM SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.SUPPORT_TICKETS t
JOIN SLA_MONITOR.PUBLIC.USERS u ON u.ID = t.USER_ID
WHERE (CASE WHEN t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT IS NULL THEN DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, CURRENT_TIMESTAMP()) ELSE DATEDIFF('hour', t.CREATED_AT, t.FIRST_RESPONSE_AT) END) > 
      (CASE UPPER(u.SERVICE_LEVEL) WHEN 'BASIC' THEN 72 WHEN 'PRO' THEN 36 WHEN 'MAX' THEN 24 END)
ORDER BY 
  CASE UPPER(u.SERVICE_LEVEL) WHEN 'MAX' THEN 1 WHEN 'PRO' THEN 2 WHEN 'BASIC' THEN 3 ELSE 4 END,
  t.CREATED_AT"}

you have claimed the task is done!

Task completed.

What I did:
- Opened the Service Standards & Operations Handbook (sla_manual.pdf) to retrieve the customer-facing SLA for initial response time and templates.
- Identified tickets exceeding the “First Reply Time” SLA using the database:
  - Max (24h): TK-1011 (34h), TK-1001 (34h)
  - Pro (36h): TK-1013 (49h), TK-1010 (44h), TK-1002 (43h), TK-1006 (41h)
  - Basic (72h): TK-1003 (86h), TK-1008 (84h), TK-1014 (80h)

Emails sent:
- Manager reminders (ordered Max → Pro → Basic, per manual):
  - To dhall@mcp.com: TK-1011 (Max), TK-1001 (Max), TK-1010 (Pro), TK-1014 (Basic)
  - To andersonp@mcp.com: TK-1013 (Pro), TK-1002 (Pro), TK-1006 (Pro), TK-1003 (Basic), TK-1008 (Basic)

- Customer apology emails (per template with second reply time):
  - TK-1011 (Max): raymondm713@mcp.com — 18 hours
  - TK-1001 (Max): donald_castillo@mcp.com — 18 hours
  - TK-1013 (Pro): anna.wright@mcp.com — 36 hours
  - TK-1010 (Pro): rbennett78@mcp.com — 36 hours
  - TK-1002 (Pro): ramosb@mcp.com — 36 hours
  - TK-1006 (Pro): awilson@mcp.com — 36 hours
  - TK-1003 (Basic): ortiza2@mcp.com — 72 hours
  - TK-1008 (Basic): hernandezj@mcp.com — 72 hours
  - TK-1014 (Basic): dsanders@mcp.com — 72 hours

Notes:
- The second reply times used are from the manual: Basic 72h, Pro 36h, Max 18h.
- Ticket TK-1000 had a first response in 3 hours and was not included.
- All emails were sent successfully.
